EdwardLoper edl NLTK Tutorial: Text Classification
Introduction
single-category text classification
Often, we wish to divide texts into categories. For example, we might want to categorize news stories by topic; or to divide sentences into questions and statements. In this tutorial, we will consider single-category text classification problems, in which:
There are a predefined set of categories.
Each text belongs to exactly one category.
Text classification
Text classification is the task of choosing the most likely category for a given text.
Relationship to Other Tasks
Single-category text classification is related to a number of other categorization problems. The following list describes how single-category text classification differs from three related problems:
In multi-category text classification, each text can have zero or more categories.
In clustering, the set of categories is not predefined.
In tagging, we attempt to categorize each element in a sequence of texts (as opposed to text classification, where we categorize individual texts).
Labeled Texts
label
Each category is uniquely identified by a label. Labels are typically strings or integers. For example, if we are classifying news stories, our category labels might include 'sports', 'technology', and 'foreign affairs'.
Categorized text types are represented using the LabeledText class, which is defined by the nltk.classifier module. New LabeledTexts are created using the LabeledText constructor:
&prompt; text = "What's your name?" &prompt; label = "question" &prompt; labeled_text = LabeledText(text, label) "What's your name?"/"question"
We may decide to change the printed representation for labeled texts; currently, it is identical to the printed representation for TaggedTypes.
A LabeledText's underlying text is accessed via the text member function; and its label is accessed via the label member function:
&prompt; labeled_text.text() "What's your name?" &prompt; labeled_text.label() "question"
labeled text token
A labeled text token is a Tokens whose type is a LabeledText:
&prompt; loc = Location(3, unit='s') @[3s] &prompt; labeled_token = Token(labeled_text, loc) "What's your name?"/"question"@[3s]
The Classifier Interface
The nltk.classifier module defines ClassifierI, a general interface for classifying texts. This interface is used by all single-category text classifiers. It requires that classifiers define two methods:
classify determines which label is most appropriate for a given text token, and returns a labeled text token with that label.
labels returns the list of category labels that are used by the classifier.
These two methods are illustrated in the following example:
&prompt; token = Token("What's your name?", loc) "What's your name?"@[3s] &prompt; my_classifier.classify(token) "What's your name?"/"question"@[3s]
&prompt; my_classifier.labels() ("statement", "imperative", "question")
Optional Methods
Classifiers are also encouraged (but not required) to define four additional methods:
prob takes a labeled text token, and returns the probability that the token's text belongs to the category indicated by the token's label.
distribution takes a text token, and returns a probability distribution, whose samples are labeled text tokens. This probability distribution indicates the likelihood that the text belongs to each label's category.
distribution_dictionary takes a text token, and returns a dictionary, mapping from each label to the probability that the text is a member of that label's category.
distribution_list takes a text token, and returns a list of probabilities, where the ith element of the list is the probability that the text belongs to the category indicated by classifier.labels()[i].
Each of these methods is illustrated in the following example:
&prompt; print labeled_token "What's your name?"/"question"@[3s]
# What's the probability that "What's your name?" is a question? &prompt; my_classifier.prob(labeled_token) 0.67
# What's the probability that "What's your name?" is a question, # given that it's not a statement? &prompt; prob_dist = my_classifier.distribution(token) &prompt; def not_statement(ltoken): ltoken.type().label()!='statement' &prompt; prob_dist.cond_prob(labeled_token, PredEvent(not_statement)) 0.85
# What is the probability for each category? &prompt; prob_dict = my_classifier.distribution_dictionary(token) &prompt; for label in prob_dict.keys(): &prompt2; print "P(%s) = %.2f" % (label, prob_dict[label]) P(statement) = 0.21 P(imperative) = 0.12 P(question) = 0.67
# What is the probability for each category? &prompt; zip(my_classifier.labels(), my_classifier.distribution_list(token)) [('statement', 0.21), ('imperative', 0.12), ('question', 0.67)]
Training Classifiers
training corpus
Often, we have access to a corpus of classified texts. This training corpus is usually hand-classified, and we assume that most of the classifications are correct.
We can use statistical methods to build classifiers from a training corpus. Some of these statistical methods are discussed in following sections.
The nltk.classifier module defines ClassifierTrainerI, a general interface for building classifiers from training corpora. It requires that classifiers define a single method, train, which takes a list of labeled tokens, and returns a new classifier. For example, the following code builds a new Naive Bayes classifier from a training corpus:
&prompt; from nltk.classifier.naivebayes import NBClassifierTrainer &prompt; classifier = NBClassifierTrainer().train(labeled_tokens) <NBClassifier: 3 labels, 187 features>
Feature-Based Classification
Features
Most text classification algorithms do not depend on the specific details of the task being performed. The same algorithms that we use to categorize documents by topic can also be used to categorize words by their part of speech, or to categorize acoustic signals according to which phoneme they represent. Features provide a standard way of encoding the information used to make classification decisions. This standard encoding abstracts away from the details of specific tasks, allowing the same classifier algorithm to be used to solve many different problems.
Each feature specifies some aspect of a LabeledText that is relevant to deciding how likely that LabeledText is to occur. These features can be used by classification algorithms to examine how likely different labels are for a given text. A typical example of a feature is:
Whether a document contains the word "ball" and has the label "sports".
Notice that features depend on both the text and the label. This allows us to specify which aspects of a text are relevant for making decisions about which labels.
feature detector functions
Features can be defined using feature detector functions, which map LabeledTexts to values. For example, the feature given above could be defined using the following function:
f(ltext) = 1 if (("ball" in ltext.text) and (ltext.label == "sports")) 0 otherwise
feature values
The feature values produced by feature detector functions are usually booleans or integers; but occasionally, real-valued features are used.
Many people use the term "feature" as we do, to refer to an aspect of a labeled text; but some people use the term to refer to the aspect's value. To avoid confusion, the following list gives explicit definitions of the terminology used by NLTK:
feature: An aspect of a LabeledText that is relevant to classification.
feature detector function: A function that defines a feature. Feature detector functions map LabeledTexts to feature values.
feature value: The value returned by a feature detector function for a particular LabeledText.
Feature Types
Boolean Features
Boolean features
Boolean features are features that generate boolean values. Boolean features are the simplest and the most common type of feature. Boolean feature detector functions usually have the form:
f(ltext) = 1 if pred(ltext.text) and (ltext.label == L) 0 otherwise
binary features
for some boolean function pred and some label L. Boolean features are also called binary features.
Boolean features have a simple probabilistic interpretation: we can think of them as events defined in the probability space of LabeledTexts.
Integer Features
Integer features
Integer features are features that generate integer values. Integer feature detector functions usually have the form:
f(ltext) = g(ltext.text) if ltext.label == L 0 otherwise
for some integer valued function g and some label L.
Integer features can be used to give classifiers access to more precise information about the text. A typical example of an integer feature detector function is:
f(ltext) = num_occurrences("ball", ltext.text) if ltext.label == "sports" 0 otherwise
Other Feature Types
Some classifier algorithms use real-valued features, or even more exotic kinds of features. NLTK allows features values to be any immutable type; but currently, NLTK only implements classifier trainers for boolean and integer features.
Feature Detectors
The nltk.classifier.feature module defines FeatureDetectorI, a general interface for implementing feature detector functions. Feature detectors are required to define a single method, detect, which takes a labeled text, and returns a feature value.
FunctionFeatureDetector provides a simple flexible implementation of the FeatureDetectorI interface. FunctionFeatureDetectors are created from Python functions with the FunctionFeatureDetector constructor:
&prompt; def ball_sports(ltext): &prompt2; return ("ball" in ltext.text()) and (ltext.label() == "sports") &prompt; fdetector = FunctionFeatureDetector(ball_sports) <FeatureDetector: ball_sports>
Once we have constructed a function detector, we can use the detect method to find the feature values for various labeled texts:
&prompt; document1 = "John threw the ball over the fence".split() &prompt; document1 = "Mary solved the equation".split() &prompt; fdetector.detect(LabeledText(document1, "sports")) 1 &prompt; fdetector.detect(LabeledText(document2, "sports")) 0 &prompt; fdetector.detect(LabeledText(document1, "foreign affairs")) 0
Feature Detector Lists
Feature detector lists
Feature detector lists are data structures that represent the feature detector functions for a set of features. Feature detector lists serve three important functions:
They provide a mechanism for grouping feature detectors together.
They associate a unique identifier with each feature detector.
They allow for efficient implementations for sets of related feature detectors.
feature id
Abstractly, a feature detector list can be thought of as a list of FeatureDetectors. The index of each feature detector in the list serves as a unique identifier for that detector's feature. This identifier is known as a feature id. The feature ids for a feature detector list with N features are 0, 1, ..., N-1.
Feature ids uniquely identify a feature, given a feature detector list. However, they are not globally unique identifiers. Thus, a single feature might have different identifiers in different feature detector lists; and two different features might have the same feature id if they are from different feature detector lists. Care must be taken not to mix feature ids from different feature detector lists.
FeatureDetectorListI
The nltk.classifier.feature module defines FeatureDetectorListI, a general interface for implementing feature detector lists. Feature detector lists are required to implement four methods: an indexing operator; a length operator; a detect method; and an addition operator.
The indexing operator
The indexing operator allows feature detector lists to be treated as lists of FeatureDetectors:
# fd_list is a feature detector list. &prompt; print fd_list <FeatureDetectorList with 6 features>
# Print the third feature detector. &prompt; fd_list[2] <FeatureDetector: ball_sports>
# Print the feature values generated for labeled_text. &prompt; labeled_text = LabeledText(document2, "foreign affairs") &prompt; for fdetector in fd_list: &prompt2; print fdetector, fdetector.detect(labeled_text) <FeatureDetector: ball_foreign_affairs> 0 <FeatureDetector: ball_weather> 0 <FeatureDetector: ball_sports> 0 <FeatureDetector: solved_foreign_affairs> 1 <FeatureDetector: solved_weather> 0 <FeatureDetector: solved_sports> 0
The length operator
The length operator returns the number of features represented by a feature detector list:
&prompt; len(fd_list) 6
The detect method
The detect method takes a labeled text, and finds the feature value for each feature detector. These values are returned in a structure called a "feature value list," which is discussed in the next section. Conceptually, the detect method is equivalent to applying each individual feature detector's detect method in parallel. The following diagram compares the use of a single feature detector to the use of a feature detector list:
FeatureDetectorI +------------------+ labeled text --> | feature detector | --> feature value +------------------+
FeatureDetectorListI FeatureValueListI +------------------+ +---------------+ | feature detector | --> | feature value | |------------------| |---------------| | feature detector | --> | feature value | |------------------| |---------------| labeled text --> | feature detector | --> | feature value | |------------------| |---------------| | . . . | --> | . . . | |------------------| |---------------| | feature detector | --> | feature value | +------------------+ +---------------+
The following example finds the feature values for document2 with label "foreign affairs":
&prompt; fd_list.detect(LabeledText(document2, "foreign affairs")) <FeatureValueList with 6 features>
The addition operator
The addition operator can be used to combine feature detector lists.
# fd_list1 and fd_list2 are feature detector lists. &prompt; print fd_list1 <FeatureDetectorList with 6 features> &prompt; print fd_list2 <FeatureDetectorList with 72 features>
&prompt; new_fd_list = fd_list1 + fd_list2 <FeatureDetectorList with 78 features>
Note that the feature ids for the feature list produced by addition may be different from the feature ids for the two constituent feature lists:
&prompt; print fd_list2[3] <FeatureDetector: running_weathers>
&prompt; print new_fd_list[3] <FeatureDetector: asleep_sports>
Efficiency
Although feature detector lists can be abstractly thought of as lists of FeatureDetectors, they are not usually implemented that way, for efficiency reasons.
Many of the features used for classification are closely related to each other. For example, a document classifier might use features that examine whether a given word is in a document. If the feature detector list were implemented as a list of independent feature detectors, then we would need to apply each feature detector separately. This would require scanning through the document once for each word we are interested in.
Instead, we can build a feature detector list that will check for all relevant words at the same time. This feature detector list makes a single pass through the document. Each time it encounters a word that we are interested in, it updates the corresponding feature value. This approach allows for significantly more efficient feature detection.
TextFunctionFDList
The nltk.classifier.feature module defines TextFunctionFDList, a flexible implementation of the FeatureDetectorListI interface. TextFunctionFDList implements feature detector lists consisting of boolean features whose detector functions have the form:
f(ltext) = 1 if (g(ltext.text) == val) and (ltext.label == L) 0 otherwise
For a given function g, and for each function value val and label L. TextFunctionFDList gets its name from the function g, since it is a function defined over texts.
TextFunctionFDLists are created using the TextFunctionFDList constructor, which takes a function, a list of function values, and a list of labels. The new feature detector list contains one feature detector for each (val, L) pair. The following example constructs a feature detector list that checks the length of an sentence:
&prompt; def length(text): return len(text) &prompt; length_range = range(0, 25) &prompt; labels = ('statement', 'imperative', 'question') &prompt; fd_list = TextFunctionFDList(length, length_range, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 75 features>
BagOfWordsFDList
The nltk.classifier.feature module also defines BagOfWordsFDList, a feature detector list implementation which checks which words are present in a text. In particular, it implements a feature detector list containing boolean features whose detector functions have the form:
f(ltext) = 1 if (w in ltext.text) and (ltext.label == L) 0 otherwise
For each word w and label L.
BagOfWordsFDLists are created using the BagOfWordsFDList constructor, which takes a list of relevant words and a list of labels. The new feature detector list contains one feature detector for each (w, L) pair. The following example constructs a feature detector list that checks sentences for the presence of several informative words:
&prompt; words = 'ball company chip score attack invade' 'ball company chip score attack invade' &prompt; wordlist = words.split() ['ball', 'company', 'chip', 'score', 'attack', 'invade'] &prompt; labels = ('sports', 'foreign affairs', 'technology') ('sports', 'foreign affairs', 'technology')
&prompt; fd_list = BagOfWordsFDList(wordlist, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 18 features>
Other Feature Detector List Implementations
The nltk.classifier.feature module provides several more feature detector list implementations; see their reference documentation for more details.
AlwaysOnFDList
SimpleFDList
LabeledTextFunctionFDList
MergedFDList
MemoizedFDList
nltk.classifier.feature also implements the AbstractFDList class, which provides a convenient basis for building custom feature detector lists. It also serves as a base class for most of the feature value lists provided by nltk.
Feature Value Lists
Feature value lists
Feature value lists are data structures that represent the feature values for a set of features. Feature value lists serve three important functions:
They provide a mechanism for grouping feature values together.
They associate a unique identifier with each feature value.
They allow for efficient encoding of sparse sets of feature values.
Abstractly, a feature value list can be thought of as a list of the feature values for a set of features. The value for the feature whose id is i is the ith element of the list.
Feature value lists are usually created with the detect method of a feature detector list. The feature ids in the feature value list correspond with the feature ids in the feature detector list that was used to create it. In other words, the ith feature detector in the feature detector list is responsible for generating the ith feature value in the feature value list. This correspondence was illustrated in the diagram used to illustrate the detect method, above.
Usually, most of the features in a FeatureValueList have the same value. For example, a sentence-type classifier might use features of the form:
f(ltext) = 1 if (w in ltext.text) and (ltext.label == L) 0 otherwise
for each word w and each label L. If there are 3 labels, and we are interested in 1,000 words, then there are 3,000 features; but for a typical sentence, only a handful of those features will have a nonzero value.
sparse default
If most of the features in a FeatureValueLists, have the same value, the FeatureValueList is said to be sparse. The common value is called the default, and is typically zero.
FeatureValueListI
The nltk.classifier.feature module defines FeatureValueListI, a general interface for implementing feature value lists. Feature value lists are required to implement four methods: an indexing operator; a length operator; an assignments method; and a default method.
The indexing operator
The indexing operator allows feature value lists to be treated as lists of feature values:
# fv_list is a feature value list. &prompt; print fv_list <FeatureValueList with 6 features>
# Print the third feature value. &prompt; fv_list[2] 0
# Print each feature value. &prompt; print [fvalue for fvalue in fv_list] [0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0]
The length operator
The length operator returns the number of features represented by a feature value list:
&prompt; len(fv_list) 6
The assignment method and the default method
The assignments method and the default method provide an efficient way of processing sparse feature value lists. default returns the feature value list's default value. This is typically the value for most features in the list. assignments returns a list of (feature-id, feature-value) pairs, which specifies the feature value for all of the remaining features.
default and assignments can be used together to efficiently process large sparse feature value lists. For example, the following code calculates the sum of all feature values in fv_list:
&prompt; assignments = fv_list.assignments() &prompt; sum = fv_list.default() * (len(fv_list)-len(assignments)) &prompt; for (fid, fval) in assignments: &prompt2; sum += fval &prompt; print sum 7
Using Classifiers
Before we start explaining how various classifiers work, we will look at a complete example of how classifiers can be used. This should help tie together the various data structures and interfaces that have been discussed so far. The task we will look at is sentence-type classification. In particular, we wish to categorize sentences as statements, imperatives, or questions. We will use a ClassifierTrainer to build a feature-based classifier from a training corpus.
Features
The first thing we need to do is decide which aspects of a sentence are relevant to this classification task. In other words, we must decide which features to use. After examining the training corpus, we might decide that the three following kinds of information are relevant:
Which words are present in the sentence
The first word of the sentence
The length of the sentence
Which words are present
To check which words are present in a sentence, we can define a BagOfWordsFDList.
&prompt; word_list = open('wordlist.txt').read().split() &prompt; labels = ('statement', 'question', 'imperative') &prompt; bag_of_words_fd_list = BagOfWordsFDList(word_list, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 1800 features>
The list of words in the file wordlist.txt indicates which words we believe are relevant to this classification task.
The first word
To check what the first word of a sentence is, we can use a TextFunctionFDList.
&prompt; first_word_list = open('firstwordlist.txt').read().split() &prompt; def first_word(text): return text[0] &prompt; first_word_fd_list = TextFunctionFDList(first_word, first_word_list, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 852 features>
The list of words in the file firstwordlist.txt indicates which first words we believe are relevant to this classification task.
Sentence length
To check the length of the sentence, we can use another TextFunctionFDList.
&prompt; def length(text): return len(text) &prompt; length_range = range(0, 25) &prompt; length_fd_list = TextFunctionFDList(length, length_range, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 75 features>
Combining the Feature Lists
Finally, we can combine these three sets of feature detectors into a single feature detector list, using the addition operator:
&prompt; fd_list = bag_of_words_fd_list + first_word_fd_list + length_fd_list <FeatureDetectorList with 2727 features>
Training Corpus
Next, we need to load the training corpus. Training corpora are often stored in different formats for different tasks. For this task, we have three files: statements.txt, imperatives.txt, and questions.txt. These files contain training samples for the types of sentences indicated by their filenames. Each file has one sentence per line. The following code reads these sentences, and labels them appropriately:
&prompt; tokenizer = LineTokenizer()
&prompt; statements = open('statements.txt').read() &prompt; statement_toks = tokenizer.tokenize(statements)
&prompt; imperatives = open('imperatives.txt').read() &prompt; imperative_toks = tokenizer.tokenize(imperatives)
&prompt; questions = open('questions.txt').read() &prompt; question_toks = tokenizer.tokenize(questions)
&prompt; train_toks = (label_tokens(statement_toks, 'statement') + &prompt2; label_tokens(imperative_toks, 'imperative') + &prompt2; label_tokens(question_toks, 'question'))
label_tokens is a simple helper function that takes a list of unlabeled tokens, and returns a corresponding list of labeled tokens.
Training the Classifier
Once we've constructed a feature list and a training corpus, we can train a new classifier. First, we build a ClassifierTrainer, using the feature detector list:
# Naive Bayes classifier trainer &prompt; trainer = NBClassifierTrainer(fd_list) <NBClassifierTrainer: 2727 features>
Then, we use the ClassifierTrainer to train a new classifier, using the training corpus:
&prompt; classifier = trainer.train(train_toks) <NBClassifier: 3 labels, 2727 features>
If we wanted to build another kind of classifier, we could simply use a different kind of ClassifierTrainer. For example, the following code uses our feature detector list and training corpus to build a new maximum entropy classifier, using a ClassifierTrainer that implements improved iterative scaling:
# Improved Iterative Scaling maxent classifier trainer &prompt; trainer = IISMaxentClassifierTrainer(fd_list) <IISMaxentClassifierTrainer: 2727 features>
&prompt; classifier = trainer.train(train_toks) <MaxentClassifier: 3 labels, 2727 features>
Classifying New Texts
Finally, we can use the classifier we built to classify new texts:
&prompt; loc = Location(3, unit='s') &prompt; test_tok = Token("Do you enjoy classification?", loc)
&prompt; classifier.classify(test_tok) "Do you enjoy classification?"/"question"@[3s]
&prompt; prob_dict = classifier.distribution_dictionary(test_tok) &prompt; for label in prob_dict.keys(): &prompt2; print "P(%s) = %.2f" % (label, prob_dict[label]) P(statement) = 0.24 P(imperative) = 0.02 P(question) = 0.74
Classifier Models
The next three sections discuss two classifier models that are implemented by nltk: the Naive Bayes classifier and the maximum entropy classifier. This discussion serves to explain the algorithms used by these classifiers; and to explore the issues that go into implementing a classifier.
AbstractFeatureClassifier
Many feature-based classification models are based on a function that estimates the likelihood of a given FeatureValueList. This likelihood indicates how probable it is that a randomly selected labeled text will produce the given FeatureValueList. These models can then classify a given text by selecting the label which maximizes the likelihood function for the text.
This general approach to classification is captured by AbstractFeatureClassifier, which is defined by the nltk.classifier.feature module. This abstract base class provides default definitions for all of the methods defined by ClassifierI.
abstract class
An abstract class is a class that is only intended for use as a base class.
These default definitions rely on the method fv_list_likelihood, which should be defined by a subclass. This method returns a likelihood estimate for a given FeatureValueList. This likelihood should be proportional to the probability of the labeled text that generated the feature value list. In other words:
fv_list_likelihood(fd_list.detect(<ext;)) ≈ Z × P(<ext;)
Where:
<ext; is a labeled text.
fd_list is the FeatureDetectorList used by the classifier.
Z is a positive normalization constant that does not depend <ext;.label().
The reason for the requirement that Z not depend on the label used to generate fv_list will become clear when we discuss how AbstractFeatureClassifier uses fv_list_likelihood. Note that this requirement is trivially satisfied if fv_list_likelihood returns the probability of the labeled text that generated the feature value list.
We use the term "likelihood" to emphasize that this value is not actually a probability. However, we do require that the likelihood be proportional to a probability.
Algorithms
This section discusses the algorithms used by AbstractFeatureClassifier to classify texts; the next section will describe how these algorithms are implemented. Let:
&t; be a text.
&l; be a label.
&Lhat;(<extlt;) = fv_list_likelihood(fd_list.detect(<extlt;))
Classifying Texts
To classify an unlabeled text t, we find the label &l; that maximizes P(&l;|&t;):
classify(&t;) = ARGMAX&l; P(&l;|&t;)
Using Bayes Rule, we can rewrite this as:
classify(&t;) = ARGMAX&l; P(<extlt;) / P(&t;)
We can then use our likelihood estimate to replace P(<extlt;):
classify(&t;) = ARGMAX&l; (&Lhat;(<extlt;) / Z) / P(&t;)
Since P(&t;) and Z do not depend on &l;, we can simplify this equation to:
classify(&t;) = ARGMAX&l; &Lhat;(<extlt;)
We can then use fv_list_likelihood to solve for &t;.
Estimating Label Probabilities
We use a similar approach for estimating the probability of a label, given a text. We wish to find P(&l;|&t;). Using Bayes Rule, we can rewrite this as:
P(&l;|&t;) = P(<extlt;) / P(&t;)
P(&t;) is equal to the sum of P(<extlt;) over all values of &l;:
P(&l;|&t;) = P(<extlt;) / ∑&lprime; P(<extlprimet;)
We can then use our likelihood estimate to replace P(<extlt;) and P(<extlprimet;):
P(&l;|&t;) = (&Lhat;(<extlt;)/Z) / ∑&lprime; (&Lhat;(<extlprimet;)/Z)
Since Z does not depend on &l;, we can cancel all of the Zs:
P(&l;|&t;) = &Lhat;(<extlt;) / ∑&lprime; &Lhat;(<extlprimet;)
We can then use fv_list_likelihood to solve for P(&l;|&t;).
Implementation
In this section, we will examine the implementation of several of the methods implemented by AbstractFeatureClassifier. For information about the methods not discussed here, see nltk/classifier/feature.py.
Constructing a New AbstractFeatureClassifier
The AbstractFeatureClassifier constructor takes two arguments: a FeatureDetectorList; and a list of labels. The constructor simply records its arguments for later use.
def __init__(self, fd_list, labels): self._fd_list = fd_list self._labels = labels
AbstractFeatureClassifier.classify()
The classify method loops through each label, looking for the label that maximizes &Lhat;(<ext;). First, it initializes a variable to hold the current maximum:
# (label, likelihood) pair that maximizes likelihood max = (None, 0)
Then it loops through each label, using fv_list_likelihood to assess that label's likelihood:
for label in self._labels: # Find &Lhat;(LabeledText(text, label)) fv_list = self._fd_list.detect(LabeledText(text, label)) l = self.fv_list_likelihood(fv_list)
# Update the maximum, if appropriate. if l > max[1]: max = (label, l)
Finally, it uses the maximum label to construct and return a new labeled token:
return Token(LabeledText(text, label), unlabeled_token.loc())
The complete listing for AbstractFeatureClassifier.classify is:
def classify(self, unlabeled_token): # (label, likelihood) pair that maximizes likelihood max = (None, 0)
# Find the label that maximizes &Lhat;(LabeledText(text, label)) for label in self._labels: fv_list = self._fd_list.detect(LabeledText(text, label)) l = self.fv_list_likelihood(fv_list) if l > max[1]: max = (label, l)
return Token(LabeledText(text, max[0]), unlabeled_token.loc())
AbstractFeatureClassifier.distribution_list()
AbstractFeatureClassifier.distribution_list returns a list that specifies the probability for each label. Its implementation is based on the equation for P(&l;|&t;) from :
P(&l;|&t;) = &Lhat;(<extlt;) / ∑&lprime; &Lhat;(<extlprimet;)
It begins by initializing variables to hold a list of &Lhat;(<ext;) values, and the the sum of these values:
l_list = [] l_sum = 0.0
It then loops through each label, updating l_list and l_sum with the likelihood value for each label:
for label in self._labels: # Find &Lhat;(LabeledText(text, label)) fv_list = self._fd_list.detect(LabeledText(text, label)) l = self.fv_list_likelihood(fv_list)
# Update l_list and l_sum l_list.append(l) l_sum += l
If &Lhat;(<ext;) was zero for all labels, it calls a zero_distribution_list. By default, this method returns a uniform distribution; but it can be overridden by subclasses.
if l_sum == 0: return self.zero_distribution_list(unlabeled_token)
Otherwise, it estimates P(&l;|&t;) by dividing each &Lhat;(<ext;) in l_list by l_sum:
return [l/l_sum for l in l_list]
The complete listing for AbstractFeatureClassifier.distribution_list is:
def distribution_list(self, unlabeled_token): text = unlabeled_token.type() q_list = [] q_sum = 0.0
# Find &Lhat;(LabeledText(text, label)) for each label for label in self._labels: fv_list = self._fd_list.detect(LabeledText(text, label)) l = self.fv_list_likelihood(fv_list) q_list.append(q) q_sum += q
# If q=0 for all labels, use zero_distribution_list if q_sum == 0: return self.zero_distribution_list(unlabeled_token)
# Normalize the probability estimates. return [q/q_sum for q in q_list]
The Naive Bayes Classifier
The Naive Bayes classifier implements a simple algorithm that can achieve relatively good performance on classification tasks. This algorithm can be used with any type of feature; but it is usually used with binary features.
Using NBClassifier
The nltk.classifier.naivebayes module defines NBClassifier, a text classifier based on the Naive Bayes classification algorithm. NBClassifier classifies texts using estimates of the probabilities for each label; and of the probabilities for each feature value of a feature, given its label. The label probability estimates are specified using a ProbDist, whose samples are labels. The feature value probability estimates are specified using a ConditionalProbDist, whose conditions are (label, feature id) pairs; and whose samples are feature values.
The NBClassifier constructor takes four arguments: a FeatureDetectorList; a list of labels; a ProbDist that provides probability estimates for labels; and a ConditionalProbDist that provides probability estimates for feature values.
# Build a new Naive Bayes classifier. &prompt; classifier = NBClassifier(fd_list, labels, &prompt2; label_pdist, fval_pdist) <NBClassifier: 3 labels, 2727 features>
NBClassifier supports all of the methods specified by ClassifierI:
&prompt; classifier.classify(token) "What's your name?"/'question' &prompt; classifier.prob(labeled_token) 0.67 &prompt; classifier.distribution(token) <ProbDist> &prompt; classifier.distribution_dictionary(token) {'statement': 0.21, 'imperative': 0.12, 'question': 0.67} &prompt; classifier.distribution_list(token) [0.21, 0.12, 0.67]
NBClassifier uses AssignmentEvents to find the probability of each feature value assignment. If the NBClassifier is to be efficient, then its probability distribution's prob() method should process AssignmentEvents efficiently. This will be discussed further in .
Algorithms
We are currently making some changes to the naive bayes implementation; some of the material in this section is currently out of date. We will update it in the near future.
This section discusses the algorithms used by NBClassifier; the next section will describe how these algorithms are implemented. Let:
&fi; be the feature whose feature id is i.
&v; be a feature value lists, where &vi; is the feature value for &fi;
Using these variables, we can write the probability for a FeatureValueList &v; as:
P(&v;) = P(&f1; = &v1;, &f2; = &v2;, ..., &fn; = &vn;)
The Naive Bayes Assumption
The Naive Bayes assumption states that each feature value assignment is probabilistically independent of all other feature value assignments. In other words:
P(&fi; = x, &fj; = y) = P(&fi; = x) × P(&fj; = y)
For all i ≠ j.
Although the Naive Bayes assumption is usually not strictly true, it is often approximately correct. Thus, we can use it to find a reasonable estimate for P(&v;):
P(&v;) = ∏ 0≤i <n P(&fi; = &vi;)
NBClassifier can then solve for P(&v;) using the probability distribution it was constructed from to find probability estimates for individual feature value assignments.
Recall that if we use AbstractFeatureClassifier as a base class, then the only method we need to implement is fv_list_likelihood, which returns a likelihood estimate for a given feature value list. Clearly, we could use this estimate of P(&v;) to implement fv_list_likelihood. However, direct implementation of this estimation formula is inefficient for sparse feature value lists.
Factoring Out Default Assignments
Since most feature value lists are sparse, NBClassifier uses the following equivalent formulation, which factors out the product of probabilities for feature assignments with default values:
P(&v;) ≈ Z × &Lhat;(&v;)
Z = ∏ 0≤i<n P(&fi; = D)
&Lhat;(&v;) = ∏{i: &vi; ≠ D} (P(&fi; = &vi;) / P(&fi; = D))
Where D is the FeatureValueList's default value (usually 0). Note that Q only depends on the non-default features of the labeled text; thus, we can efficiently calculate its value using the assignments method.
Z is a constant, so it does depend on the label used to generate &v;. We can therefore use &Lhat; as our likelihood estimate.
There is a minor problem with the formulation of &Lhat; that is presented here: if P(&fi; = D) is 0 for any feature, then the given equation will produce division by zero. We can avoid this problem by excluding all features where P(&fi;=D) is 0 from Z; and not dividing by P(&fi;=D) in &Lhat;. This gives the modified formula:
&Lhat;(&v;) = ∏{i: &vi; ≠ D and P(&fi; = D) ≠ 0} P(&fi; = &vi;) / P(&fi; = D)
NBClassifier Implementation
We are currently making some changes to the naive bayes implementation; some of the material in this section is currently out of date. We will update it in the near future.
NBClassifier is implemented as a subclass of AbstractFeatureClassifier. This base class handles most of the classifier's work; NBClassifier itself only needs to implement a few simple methods. The NBClassifier constructor records the probability distribution it is given, and calls its base constructor:
def __init__(self, fd_list, labels, prob_dist): self._prob_dist = prob_dist AbstractFeatureClassifier.__init__(self, fd_list, labels)
The fv_list_likelihood method is a straight-forward implementation of the algorithm discussed in .
&Lhat;(&v;) = ∏{i: &vi; ≠ D and P(&fi; = D) ≠ 0} P(&fi; = &vi;) / P(&fi; = D)
def fv_list_likelihood(self, fv_list): l = 1.0 default = fv_list.default()
# Loop through each non-default value. for (fid, val) in fv_list.assignments():
# Find the probability of fv_list's value and the # probability of the default value for this feature. p1 = self._prob_dist.prob(AssignmentEvent((fid, val))) p2 = self._prob_dist.prob(AssignmentEvent((fid, default)))
# Update the likelihood. if p2 != 0: l *= p1 / p2
return l
The note at the end of explains why we must check that p2 ≠ 0.
NBClassifier also implements prob_dist, which returns the probability distribution that the classifier uses to estimate probabilities of feature value assignments; and a string representation operator. The complete listing for NBClassifier is:
class NBClassifier(AbstractFeatureClassifier): def __init__(self, fd_list, labels, prob_dist): self._prob_dist = prob_dist AbstractFeatureClassifier.__init__(self, fd_list, labels)
def fv_list_likelihood(self, fv_list): p = 1.0 default = fv_list.default() for (fid, val) in fv_list.assignments(): p1 = self._prob_dist.prob(AssignmentEvent((fid, val))) p2 = self._prob_dist.prob(AssignmentEvent((fid, default))) if p2 != 0: p *= p1 / p2 return p
def prob_dist(self): return self._prob_dist
def __repr__(self): return ('<NBClassifier: %d labels, %d features>' % (len(self.labels()), len(self.fd_list())))
Training the Naive Bayes Classifier
We are currently making some changes to the naive bayes implementation; some of the material in this section is currently out of date. We will update it in the near future.
The nltk.classifier.naivebayes module defines NBClassifierTrainer, a factory class for Naive Bayes classifiers. NBClassifierTrainers are created with the NBClassifierTrainer constructor, which takes a single FeatureDetectorList:
&prompt; trainer = NBClassifierTrainer(fd_list) <NBClassifierTrainer: 2727 features>
Currently, NBClassifierTrainer only supports binary features.
NBClassifierTrainers can be used to build new NBClassifiers from lists of training tokens, using the train method:
&prompt; classifier = trainer.train(train_toks) <NBClassifier: 3 labels, 2727 features>
Implementation
NBClassifierTrainer's train method consists of four simple steps:
Create a new frequency distribution. This frequency distribution will form the basis for the probability distribution that the NBClassifier uses to estimate probabilities of feature value assignments.
Populate the frequency distribution with the FeatureValueLists for each of the training tokens.
Use the frequency distribution to build a probability distribution.
Use the probability distribution to build a NBClassifier.
For now, we will skip the first step, and assume that we already have an empty frequency distribution freq_dist. To implement the second step, we simply loop over the training tokens, incrementing the count for each token's feature value list:
&prompt; for tok in train_toks: &prompt2; freq_dist.inc(fd_list.detect(tok.type()))
For the third step, we can use the MLEProbDist class to convert the frequency distribution into a probability distribution:
&prompt; prob_dist = MLEProbDist(freq_dist)
To smooth the probability distribution distribution, we might use some statistical estimator other than MLE. To do so, we would simply use a different ProbDist, such as LaplaceProbDist. The implementation of NBClassifierTrainer in the toolkit allows you to specify which statistical estimation you would like to use, via the keyword argument estimator. See the reference documentation for NBClassifier.train for more details.
To implement the fourth step, we simply call the NBClassifier constructor:
&prompt; return NBClassifier(self._fd_list, labels, probdist)
The only task remaining is to construct the frequency distribution. Although a SimpleFreqDist could be used, it would result in very poor performance; instead, NBClassifierTrainer uses a frequency distribution that is optimized for finding the probabilities of AssignmentEvents: NBClassifierFreqDist.
NBClassifierFreqDist
NBClassifierFreqDist is a relatively simple frequency distribution that's specialized for use with NBClassifier. By placing restrictions on the types of samples and events that the probability distribution supports, NBClassifierFreqDist can be made quite efficient. The restrictions that NBClassifierFreqDist employs are:
Samples be boolean C{FeatureValueList}s of fixed length.
The freq method only supports AssignmentEvents.
The count method only supports AssignmentEvents.
The methods samples, cond_samples, B, bins, Nr, max, cond_max, and cond_freq are not supported.
Internally, NBClassifierFreqDist keeps track of the samples for which each feature has been active (fcount[id]); and the total number of samples (N). From these values, it can calculate the number of samples that are contained in a given AssignmentEvent:
count(AssignmentEvent(id, 1)) = fcount[id]
count(AssignmentEvent(id, 0)) = N - fcount[id]
Similarly, it can calculate the frequency for a given AssignmentEvent:
freq(AssignmentEvent(id, 1)) = fcount[id]/N
freq(AssignmentEvent(id, 0)) = 1 - fcount[id]/N
NBClassifierFreqDist uses an array to store fcount. Arrays are efficient data structures for storing homogeneous data; they are defined by the Numeric module. In most cases, they can be accessed like lists. The function zeros can be used to create a new array of a given length, all of whose elements are zero.
The implementation of NBClassifierFreqDist is straight-forward:
class NBClassifierFreqDist(FreqDistI):
def __init__(self, fv_list_size): self._fcount = zeros(fv_list_size) self._N = 0.0
def N(self): return self._N
def inc(self, sample): self._N += 1
# Increment the feature count array for (fid,val) in sample.assignments(): if val != 0: self._fcount[fid] += 1
def freq(self, event): (fid, value) = event.assignment() if value: return (self._fcount[fid] / self._N) else: return 1 - (self._fcount[fid] / self._N)
def count(self, event): (fid, value) = event.assignment() if value: return self._fcount[fid] else: return self._N - self._fcount[fid]
Although the implementation described here is sufficient for use with simple probability distribution, such as MLEProbDist, we need to implement more methods to allow more complex probability distributions to be used. For this reason, the version of NBClassifierFreqDist implemented in nltk.classifier.naivebayes supports several additional methods; and will likely grow to support even more methods.
The Maximum Entropy Classifier
One problem with the Naive Bayes classifier is that its performance depends on the degree to which the features are independent. But the feature sets used for classification are rarely independent; and often, we wish to use features which are highly dependent on each other. Under these circumstances, NaiveBayesClassifier tends to give poor performance. One alternative is to use a different classifier model.
maximum entropy
The maximum entropy classifier can use mutually dependent features to reliably classify texts. This classifier is based on the idea that we should "model all that is known and assume nothing about that which is unknown." To accomplish this goal, we considers all classifiers that are "empirically consistent" with a set of training data; and chooses the classifier that maximizes entropy.
Emperical Consistency
empirically consistent
A classifier is empirically consistent with a set of training data if its estimate for the frequency of each feature is equal to the actual frequency of that feature in the training data. In other words:
∑<ext; Pclassifier(<ext;) × &fdilt; = ∑<ext; freqtraining(<ext;) × &fdilt;
for all i, where:
Pclassifier(<ext;) is the classifier's estimated probability for <ext;.
freqtraining(<ext;) is the frequency of <ext; in the training data.
In general, the more features we use, the stronger the constraints that emperical consistency puts on the classifier. At one extreme, if we use no features, then any classifier will be empirically consistent with any training set. At the other extreme, if we use one feature for each possible labeled text, then only one classifier will be empirically consistent with a given training set.
It seems reasonable to require our classifier to be empirically consistent with the training data. It is this requirement allows our classifier to capture the structure of the training data. However, it is not immediately obvious why we should want to choose the classifier that maximizes entropy.
The Principle of Maximum Entropy
entropy
A classifier's entropy provides a measure of how predictable that classifier's decisions are: the higher a classifier's entropy, the more randomly it behaves. For example:
A classifier that always categorizes texts using the same label has an entropy of zero.
A classifier that randomly classifies texts into categories (each with equal probability) has a very high entropy.
The intuition behind maximizing entropy is that classifiers with lower entropy introduce biases that are not justified. In order to avoid these biases, we must pick the classifier with the highest entropy. This is most easily seen with an example.
Consider the task of classifying numerical expressions as distances, volumes, dates, counts, or monetary amounts. Examining our training corpus, we notice that 3/10 of the numerical expressions are distances or volumes. There are an infinite number of classifiers that are consistent with this statistic. For example, we could hypothesize the following category probabilities:
Category Probability
distance 0.1
volume 0.2
date 0.6
count 0.1
monetary amount 0.0
But this classifier introduces biases that are not justified by what we know about the training data. For example, we have no reason to believe that dates are significantly more common than counts, or that monetary amounts never occur. In contrast, the empirically consistent distribution that maximizes entropy does not introduce any such biases:
Category Probability
distance 0.15
volume 0.15
date 0.23333
count 0.23333
monetary amount 0.23333
For simple examples like the one presented here, we can find the maximum entropy classifier by hand. However, for classification tasks involving many mutually dependent features, we must employ more advanced methods.
The Conditional Exponential Model
In , we said that we can find the maximum entropy classifier by considering all classifiers that are empirically consistent with the training data, and choosing the classifier that maximizes entropy. However, there are an infinite number of classifiers that are empirically consistent with the training data. Fortunately, it can be proven that the maximum entropy classifier will always have the same form. In particular, the empirically consistent classifier that maximizes entropy can always be expressed as:
P(<ext;) = Z(&t;) × &Lhat;
&Lhat; = ∏i &wi; fdi(<ext;)
weights conditional exponential model
Where &wi; are a set of model parameters, called weights; and Z(&t;) is a normalizing factor that does not depend on &l;. This form is known as the conditional exponential model.
The conditional exponential model is sometimes expressed with the following equivalent formula:
P(&l;|&t;) = Z × exp ( ∑i &lambdai; × fdi(<ext;) )
Where &lambdai; = log(&wi;)
Thus, the problem of finding the maximum entropy model for a classification task reduces to the problem of finding the best conditional exponential model. Usually, this best model is found by iteratively refining a conditional exponential model's weights, until we arrive at the maximum entropy model.
Weights
Informally, the weights that paramaterize the conditional exponential model can be thought of as indications of how each feature affects classification decisions:
If a weight is one, then the corresponding feature has no effect on classification decisions.
If a weight is greater than one, then the corresponding feature will increase probability estimates for labels that cause the feature to fire. Greater values cause a greater increase.
If a weight is less than one, then the corresponding feature will decrease probability estimates for labels that cause the feature to fire. Lesser values cause a greater increase.
ConditionalExponentialClassifier
The conditional exponential classifier model is implemented by ConditionalExponentialClassifier, which is defined by the nltk.classifier.maxent module. The ConditionalExponentialClassifier constructor takes three arguments: a FeatureDetectorList; a list of labels; and a list of weights:
# Define the features and labels used by the classifier. &prompt; fd_list = BagOfWordsFDList(word_list, labels) <FeatureDetectorList with 8 features> &prompt; labels = ('statement', 'imperative', 'question') ('statement', 'imperative', 'question')
# Define the weights by hand. Each weight corresponds to a feature # in fd_list. &prompt; weights = [0.4, 1.0, 2.2, 0.1, 10.0, 3.8, 1.1, 0.3] [0.4, 1.0, 2.2, 0.1, 10.0, 3.8, 1.1, 0.3]
# Build a new conditional exponential classifier. &prompt; classifier = ConditionalExponentialClassifier(fd_list, labels, weights) <ConditionalExponentialClassifier: 3 labels, 8 features>
ConditionalExponentialClassifier supports all of the methods specified by ClassifierI:
&prompt; classifier.classify(token) "What's your name?"/'question' &prompt; classifier.prob(labeled_token) 0.5 &prompt; classifier.distribution(token) <ProbDist> &prompt; classifier.distribution_dictionary(token) {'statement': 0.4, 'imperative': 0.1, 'question': 0.5} &prompt; classifier.distribution_list(token) [0.1, 0.4, 0.5]
Implementation
ConditionalExponentialClassifier is implemented as a subclass of AbstractFeatureClassifier. This base class handles most of the classifier's work; ConditionalExponentialClassifier itself only needs to implement a few simple methods.
The ConditionalExponentialClassifier constructor records the weights it is given, and calls its base constructor:
def __init__(self, fd_list, labels, weights): self._weights = weights AbstractFeatureClassifier.__init__(self, fd_list, labels)
The fv_list_likelihood method calculates the value of &Lhat; for a given LabeledText:
&Lhat; = ∏i &wi; fdi(<ext;)
Notice that for any feature whose value &fdilt; is zero, the corresponding term &wi;&fdilt; in the product is one; so we can reduce this equation to:
&Lhat; = ∏{i: &fdilt; ≠ 0} &wi; fdi(<ext;)
In other words, we only need to consider the features that do not have the default value of zero. These are exactly the features that are returned by the FeatureValueList's assignments method. fv_list_likelihood is a straight-forward implementation of this formula:
def fv_list_likelihood(self, fv_list): prod = 1.0 for (fid, val) in fv_list.assignments(): prod *= (self._weights[id] ** val) return prod
ConditionalExponentialClassifier also provides the weights and set_weights methods for returning and updating its weights weights; and a string representation operator.The complete listing for ConditionalExponentialClassifier is:
class ConditionalExponentialClassifier(AbstractFeatureClassifier):
def __init__(self, fd_list, labels, weights, **kwargs): self._weights = weights AbstractFeatureClassifier.__init__(self, fd_list, labels)
def fv_list_likelihood(self, fv_list): prod = 1.0 for (id, val) in fv_list.assignments(): prod *= (self._weights[id] ** val) return prod
def weights(self): return self._weights
def set_weights(self, weights): self._weights = weights
def __repr__(self): return ('<ConditionalExponentialClassifier: %d labels, %d features>' % (len(self._labels), len(self._fd_list)))
Training Maximum Entropy Classifiers
generalized iterative scaling improved iterative scaling
The nltk.classifier.maxent module defines two ClassifierTrainers that can be used to build maximum entropy classifiers: GISMaxentClassifierTrainer and IISMaxentClassifierTrainer. Both of these ClassifierTrainers use an iterative algorithm to successively refine a ConditionalExponentialClassifier until they converge on the maximum entropy classifier. The algorithm employed by GISMaxentClasifierTrainer is known as generalized iterative scaling; and the algorithm used by IISMaxentClasifierTrainer is called improved iterative scaling.
The next two sections give a brief introduction to each algorithm, and describe how to use their ClassifierTrainers. A complete explanation of these algorithms is beyond the scope of this tutorial; see for references to more complete descriptions.
Generalized Iterative Scaling
Generalized iterative scaling is a procedure to find the ConditionalExponentialModel weights that define the maximum entropy classifier for a given feature set and training corpus. This procedure is guaranteed to converge on the correct weights.
Generalized iterative scaling places three constraints on the feature set:
Feature values must be boolean (i.e., 0 or 1).
The feature value list for every LabeledText must have at least one feature with a value of 1.
The sum of the feature values for each LabeledText must have the same value. In other words, there must exist a single value C such that:
∑i &fdilt; = C
correction constant
for every LabeledText <ext;. C is known as the correction constant.
The second constraint can always be satisfied by adding a single feature detector that always returns a value of one. The third constraint can always be satisfied by adding a "correction" feature that returns C-∑i&fdilt;.
In general, adding new features can change which classifier is the maximum entropy classifier for a given task. However, these two new features are completely dependent on the other features. They add no new information, and therefore place no new constraints on the classifier. As a result, they will not affect which classifier is the maximum entropy classifier.
Generalized iterative scaling begins by initializing each weight to 1. It then iteratively updates the weights using the formula:
&wi; := &wi; × ((∑<ext; freqtraining(<ext;) × &fdilt;) / (∑<ext; Pclassifier(<ext;) × &fdilt;)) ** (1/C)
Where:
freqtraining(<ext;) is the frequency of <ext; in the training data.
Pclassifier(<ext;) is the classifier's estimated probability for <ext;.
C is the correction constant.
To avoid summing over all values of <ext; (which would be very inefficient), we can make the following approximation:
∑<ext; Pclassifier(<ext;) × &fdilt; ≈ ∑&t; ∑&l; freqtraining(&t;) × Pclassifier(&l;|&t;) × &fdiltextlt;
I make the claim that feature values must be boolean -- is that true? Or do they have to be integer? non-negative integer? real? non-negative real? The current implementation assumes binary features; but if the algorithm doesn't make that requirement, I could change the implementation to work with other feature types.
GISMaxentClassifierTrainer
The nltk.classifier.maxent module defines GISMaxentClassifierTrainer, a classifier trainer based on the generalized iterative scaling algorithm. For a given training sets, GISMaxentClassifierTrainer creates a ConditionalExponentialModel that represents the maximum entropy classifier.
The GISMaxentClassifierTrainer constructor takes a single FeatureDetectorList, which encodes the features that will be used by the classifiers it creates.
&prompt; classifier = GISMaxentClassifierTrainer(fd_list) <GISMaxentClassifierTrainer: 13318 features>
The train method is used to train a new classifier from a given set of training tokens:
&prompt; classifier.train(train_toks) <ConditionalExponentialClassifier: 72 labels, 13318 features>
The train method takes a number of optional keyword arguments:
C: specifies the correction constant. This constant must satisfy the constraint:
C ≥ ∑i&fdilt;
for every LabeledText <ext;. Lower values of C cause GIS to converge more quickly. Thus, you should usually pick the lowest value that you are sure satisfies the above constraint. The default value of C is the length of the FeatureDetectorList, which is guaranteed to be safe for binary-valued features. However, this default value may result in very slow convergence.
debug: specifies whether to output messages describing the trainer's progress. Higher values result in more verbose output. The default value is zero, which indicates that no messages should be produced.
labels: specifies the set of possible labels. If none is given, then the set of all labels attested in the training data will be used.
iterations: specifies the maximum number of iterations for the GIS algorithm.
accuracy_cutoff: specifies what accuracy value should be taken to indicate convergence. If the accuracy becomes closer to one than the specified value, then GIS will terminate. The default value is None, which indicates that no accuracy cutoff should be used.
delta_accuracy_cutoff: specifies what change in accuracy should be taken to indicate convergence. If the accuracy changes by less than this value in a single iteration, then GIS will terminate. The default value is None, which indicates that no accuracy-change cutoff should be used.
log_likelihood_cutoff: specifies what log-likelihood value should be taken to indicate convergence. If the log-likelihood becomes closer to zero than the specified value, then GIS will terminate. The default value is None, which indicates that no log-likelihood cutoff should be used.
delta_log_likelihood_cutoff: specifies what change in log-likelihood should be taken to indicate convergence. If the log-likelihood changes by less than this value in a single iteration, then GIS will terminate. The default value is None, which indicates that no log-likelihood-change cutoff should be used.
Iterative Iterative Scaling
Improved iterative scaling is a procedure to find the ConditionalExponentialModel weights that define the maximum entropy classifier for a given feature set and training corpus. This procedure is guaranteed to converge on the correct weights. It usually converges more quickly than generalized iterative scaling.
Improved iterative scaling begins by initializing each weight to 1. It then iteratively updates the weights using the formula:
&wi; := &wi; × e δi
Where δi is the solution to the equation:
∑<ext; freqtraining(<ext;) × &fdilt; = ∑ <ext; Pclassifier(<ext;) × &fdilt; × e δ × nf(<ext;)
To avoid summing over all values of <ext; (which would be very inefficient), we can make the following approximation:
∑<ext; Pclassifier(&l;|&t;) × &fdilt; × e δ × nf(<ext;) ≈
∑&t; ∑&l; freqtraining(&t;) × Pclassifier(&l;|&t;) × &fdiltextlt; × e δ × nf(<ext;)
For each iteration, δi can be found using Newton's method.
IISMaxentClassifierTrainer
The nltk.classifier.maxent module defines IISMaxentClassifierTrainer, a classifier trainer based on the improved iterative scaling algorithm. For a given training sets, IISMaxentClassifierTrainer creates a ConditionalExponentialModel that represents the maximum entropy classifier.
The IISMaxentClassifierTrainer constructor takes a single FeatureDetectorList, which encodes the features that will be used by the classifiers it creates.
&prompt; classifier = IISMaxentClassifierTrainer(fd_list) <IISMaxentClassifierTrainer: 13318 features>
The train method is used to train a new classifier from a given set of training tokens:
&prompt; classifier.train(train_toks) <ConditionalExponentialClassifier: 72 labels, 13318 features>
The train method supports all of the optional keyword arguments that were described for GISMaxentClassifierTrainer (except C, since IIS does not use a correction constant).
Feature Selection
Features are used to specify which information is relevant to a classification task. Unfortunately, it's often difficult to decide which information is relevant. One possible solution would be to include a large number of features, and let the classification algorithm decide which information is relevant.
over-fitting
However, this approach has some serious disadvantages. The number of features affects the classifier's speed. Including a large number of features can result in long training and classification times. An even more serious problem arises because the number of model parameters increases with the number of features. If we use too many features, we may not be able to reliably estimate the correct values for all of these parameters. This can result in over-fitting, where the classifier models the idiosyncrasies of the training set, rather than the class of texts that the training set represents. In an extreme example of over-fitting, the classifier might assign a probability of zero to any labeled text not included in the training data.
feature selection
A more promising approach is to begin with a large number of features, and use statistical techniques to decide which features are relevant. A classifier can then be constructed from this reduced set of features. This task of deciding which features are relevant for a classification task is known as feature selection.
The nltk.classifier.featureselection module defines interfaces and classes for performing feature selection. Currently, this module only provides the basic framework for performing feature selection, and a few simple feature selectors; it does not implement any advanced feature selection techniques. However, we plan to add new feature detectors to this module in the near future.
FeatureSelectorI
The nltk.classifier.featureselection module defines FeatureSelectorI, a general interface for performing feature selection. It requires that classifiers define a single method, select, which takes a FeatureDetectorList, and decides which features are relevant for classification. It returns a new FeatureDetectorList that includes the feature detectors for the relevant features.
&prompt; print fd_list <FeatureDetectorList with 26193 features> &prompt; selected_fd_list = feature_selector.select(fd_list) <FeatureDetectorList with 1827 features>
SelectedFDList
Feature selectors decide which features are relevant for a particular classification task; and return a new FeatureDetectorList containing those features' detectors. SelectedFDList provides feature selectors with a convenient way of building this new FeatureDetectorList.
base FeatureDetectorList
A SelectedFDList consists of a subset of the feature detectors defined by a base FeatureDetectorList. The SelectedFDList constructor takes a base FeatureDetectorList and a list of feature ids, specifying which features should be included:
&prompt; print fd_list <FeatureDetectorList with 26193 features>
# Select every 50th feature. &prompt; ids = range(0, 26193, 50) [0, 50, 100, 150, 200, 250, 300, 350, 400, 450, 500, ...] &prompt; selected_fd_list = SelectedFDList(fd_list, ids) <FeatureDetectorList with 524 features>
Internally, SelectedFDList maintains a dictionary mapping from old feature ids to new feature ids. When the SelectedFDList is applied to a text, it first applies its base FeatureDetectorList to the text. Then, it uses its dictionary to transform the resulting FeatureValueList.
Feature Selectors
For information about the feature selectors currently available, see the reference documentation for the nltk.classifier.featureselection module.
